VI. Emergency Action Procedures

1. Emergency Actions and Responsibilities 

A. Alert all employees of the emergency. Evacuate (see evacuation map).

B. Assess the situation to the immediate threat of the following and begin implementing this plan within minutes:

A. Human health and other living species on the site and off location.
B. Environmental concerns, including air, water and soil. 
C. Shut down equipment
D. Evacuate all personnel on location who are not designated coordinators. 
E. Identify types of materials, estimate quantities, and assess the nature of the problem
F. Alert down wind if necessary; neighbors, public centers, schools, hospitals, retirement complexes.
G. Alert local authorities listed in you plan, i.e., fire, police, traffic, contractors, government agencies.
H. Control spreading of emergency situation by following you action plan identified in this text. 
I. Isolate runoff material. Contain excess water, chemicals, liquid fertilizer, fuel, etc., in the area designated on your containment map. Restrict these materials to the smallest area possible. 
J. Prevent large contamination of water wells, private property, public waterways, streams, sewers, rivers, canals, and natural drainage areas. 
K. Control traffic, both vehicle and human.
L. Use Protective clothing.

C.Within a mile radius, make a list of the names and phone numbers of the places that are the most likely to receive vapor, smoke or toxic fumes in the event of an emergency. Use Additional paper, if necessary.

VI. Emergency Action Procedures (continued)

2. Emergency Actions For Hurricane or Tornado Storms

A. Inspect and secure all exterior fixtures likely to be damaged by high winds.
 
B. Inspect and secure all doors and window areas with Plywood or other solid, non-breakable material.

C. Shut down all plant process; close all liquid lines; close all liquid values.

D. Brace all unsupported structures of high elevation or lower portable equipment when possible.

E. Where possible, shut down all power sources, main circuits, or entire services form external power sources.

F. Store perishable materials indoors, when possible, or under cover.

G. Protect Company records from wind and rain, or possible flooding

H. Update backup record on computer programs and move them to a protected area. 

I. Protect daily activities such as customer invoices, receipts, or other valuable transactions by duplication or removing from possible damage area. 

J. Fill all empty vertical storage vessels with liquid or ballast, or tie down using approved securing procedures. 

K. Assemble, or upon short notice before the storm, be prepared to maintain the following supplies and equipment in a central, secure location; lighting; lumber and nails; sandbags; tar paper or vinyl covers; tarps; shovels; power tools; fuel; power generators ( portable); manual tools; water; foods; first aid.







VII. Spill Policy

A. Spills of any type material, hazardous or not, are to be cleaned up immediately. 
B. Spills are defined as any release, whether accidental or accumulations of transferring materials, that exceed regulatory accumulations recommended for the

product
C. Any combination of materials that collect, impregnated or contribute to eventual contamination of equipment, wildlife, environment, or air.
D. Under no circumstances shall anyone wash a spill off the pavement, road, or property without a thorough cleanup and disposal plan. Alert the necessary personnel or agencies, depending on the extent of the release.
E. Follow the prepared Emergency Plan in other part of this plan. See complete spill cleanup procedures in Safety Manual.
F. Prepare a report.


VIII. Community Awareness Plan

A. This plan is carefully prepared to isolate, reduce and minimize hazardous material releases to the air, ground, or water.
B. The purpose of this Contingency Plan is to educate this community to product and process we have at this location
C. All safeguards, operating procedures and approved methods related to this industry are maximized to ensure that the general public is protected from excessive exposure in the event of any emergency.
D. We encourage the local authorities to familiarize themselves with this plan and our facilities so that an effective and safe process can be implemented to ensure the general public safety.














IX. Response Units, Guidelines 

1. Police, Rescue, Fire Department, Etc.

A. Contact Operations Manager.
B. Notify others in the front section of this plan (as necessary).
C. Set up a command post.
D. Follow evacuation plan in this section.
E. Wear protective clothing.
F. Be prepared in the event of a pesticide fire for liquid pesticide drum explosions.
G. Control and protect surrounding structures. Do not use excessive water on pesticide fire.
H.  Do not use direct spray and high pressure on chemical fire.
I. Use fog spray or vapor. 
J. Consider foam where possible.
K. Know poison symptoms and post precautions.
L. After emergency, remove contaminated clothing, shower thoroughly, and clean clothes separately from uncontaminated clothing

2. This location is best described as: Bulk Fertilizer

Liquid Plant

3. The five most hazardous products at this location are: (list names and identify the product as flammable, nonflammable, corrosive, reactive , explosive, other)

a. Ammonia-nonflammable gas-toxic
b. Fuadan 4 F-Poisonous
c. Gramoxone Extra-Poisonous
d. Counter 15-G-Poisonous
e. Lorsban 15-G-Poisonous

4. What is the average monthly inventory of these five (5) products?

A. 70 ton
B. 20 Gal.
C. 4 Gal. 
D. 2000 lbs. 
E. 2000 lbs.

5.On the following page list your recommended control of these products in the event of a release.



IX. Response Units, Guidelines (continued)

6.List your control of your hazardous products below: 

a. NH3 - evacuate downwind ? mile; corrosive - irritating to all living species; use mist or water spray to control vapor; use water for skin contact, wash 15 minutes; control runoff; use safety protective clothing and breathing apparatus; stay upwind; do not use water on liquid NH3.
b. Pesticide spills - contain spill, wash off with water, then soap & water.

7. Briefly describe your pesticide storage. Give details of floor drains, emergency exits, sprinklers, firewalls, and other types of structures, i.e. Wood, metal concrete, etc.

Pesticides are stored in a 60' x 80' steel warehouse with a concrete floor. Warehouse has no drains, sprinklers, or other safety devices. Doors are located on all four sides. No windows. 22' x 18' chemical dike in Northeast corner.

8. In the event of a fire at your location, describe the runoff area and the necessary procedure to isolate the runoff from causing further damage to water, air and soil. If more than one structure, consider each building separately. 

Runoff from the warehouse would go north into the diked loading area. In case of a chemical fire, water should not be allowed to enter this area.
